title: 7 Bridges Walk Ballater Route

images.title: Stanley Howe / Ballater
images.caption: Ballater. The town developed in the late 18th century, first as a spa resort to accommodate visitors to the Pannanich Mineral Well. There are many victorian buildings in the town today. The arrival of the railway in 1866 brought an increase in tourism to the area. The station was closed in 1966 but is now used as a visitor centre with historical exhibitions.

images.title: Alan Findlay / The Royal Bridge, Ballater
images.caption: The Royal Bridge, Ballater. The town has strong royal connections as Balmoral Castle, the British Royal Family's holiday home, lies a few miles to the west. The family has visited the town frequently since the time of Queen Victoria.

images.title: Stanley Howe / Upstream River Dee
images.caption: Upstream River Dee. The river is famous for its salmon fishing.

images.caption: Fields below the Bridge of Gairn

description: This popular circular walk takes you around the town of Ballater, visiting several bridges on the River Dee and the River Muick. The walk runs for just over 5 miles with some lovely riverside paths, peaceful woodland trails and great views of the surrounding Cairngorms Mountains. The walk starts in the town centre and follows the waymarked path to Ballater Bridge where you cross the river. You then follow the South Deeside Road to the Bridge of Muick, where you cross the River Muick. The next section heads north west along The Avenue which runs through Dalhefour Wood. Here you have the option of taking a small detour and visiting Knock Castle, just to the west of the path. The four-storey ruin, dates from approximately 1600 and has an interesting history. After leaving Dalhefour Wood you cross the river on Polhollick Bridge, a white iron suspension bridge dating from the late 19th century. You then turn east to follow a riverside path to the Bridge of Gairn. Here you cross the River Gairn and turn south east to follow the trail along the Dee and back into the town centre. To continue your walking around Ballater, head west and visit the Balmoral Estate. Here you can try the interesting Balmoral Cairns Walk which visits the historic castle and a series of cairns dedicated to members of the British royal family and events in their lives. Ballater is located close to both Loch Muick and Loch Kinord where there's some lovely waterside paths to try.
